General form $$\frac{dy}{dt} + p(t)y = g(t)$$

Multiply by $\mu(t)$ and change to product rule; integrate

We can in fact find that for the general form $$\mu(t) = \exp \int p(t)dt$$ and that $$y(t) = \frac 1 {\mu(t)} \left[ \int _{t_0} ^t \mu(s)g(s)ds + C \right]$$

General form $$\frac{dy}{dx} = f(x,y)$$

We want to discuss a subclass of functions. We write $$M(x,y) + N(x,y)\frac{dy}{dx} = 0$$ (usually by letting $M(x,y) = -f(x,y)$ and $N(x,y) = 1$, but there are other ways).

Then, if $M$ is a function of only $x$ and $N$ of only $y$, we have $$M(x) + N(y)\frac{dy}{dx} = 0$$ which can be separated and directly integrated.
